_microblog.bio: Feminist, futurist, father. Autonomous biological machine. Modern Hebrew. Software developer.

items.content_html:
Today was my first day as a software developer at Modern Energy! I‚Äôm thrilled to be joining the fight to mitigate climate change.

Special thanks to Luke VanderHart for introducing me, and to Bret Victor for his inspiring essay What can a Technologist do About Climate Change?
Voted! blog.aviflax.com
@danielpunkass congrats!

Happy Indigenous Peoples‚Äô Day!

If you‚Äôre a US resident, take a few minutes to learn what it might look like if the US honored its treaties with indigenous peoples.

Holyüí© Coda is amazing. Truly impressive, compelling, fantastic!

Yesterday I learned via this answer a handy Atom trick: one can exclude directories from the Find in Project feature by prefixing them with an exclamation mark, like so: !dir

This is handy when a project contains ‚Äúarchived‚Äù (frozen) files, or a generated dir like Jekyll‚Äôs _site.
I just randomly tried to run pico ‚Äî wow, blast from the past!

I spoke at the Clojure/conj last week, on (Architecture) Diagrams as ‚ú®Data‚ú®

I‚Äôm very happy with how it came out. Thank you to everyone who helped me prepare and everyone who gave me feedback!

If you‚Äôd like, you can check out the description, the slides, or the video.

ü§î It‚Äôd be handy if I could assign a title to a given browser window ‚Äî¬†i.e. a set of tabs ‚Äî¬†so I could group sets of tabs by activity or topic.

It looks like there are a few Firefox extensions that do this, but it‚Äôs unclear how effective they are on MacOS. I‚Äôll have to try them.

On a lark, I just installed Lynx and used it to view the homepage of the FC4 Framework. It looked great! I got a real kick out of this; it took me way back. I was also pleased to see that the structure and content of the page worked well when represented in plain text.
@danielpunkass omg that looks super yum I‚Äôve gotta get back there haven‚Äôt been in years!

I just released a new version of FC4, a FLOSS framework for authoring, publishing, and maintaining C4 software architecture diagrams. The (abbreviated) highlights: Rendering multiple diagrams is faster and more efficient The versioning scheme has changed to work better with Homebrew ... blog.aviflax.com

Anyone else use an iPad with an external keyboard (Bluetooth in my case) and found that Safari is really flaky when it comes to responding to keyboard shortcuts? Maybe there‚Äôs some kind of focus thing I‚Äôm missing, but I‚Äôve been really annoyed by this apparent bug.

I just used Proporti.onl to estimate the gender distribution of my Twitter followers and those I follow, based on their profile descriptions or first names. It‚Äôs not great: 1% non-binary, 36% women, 62% men. I‚Äôm gonna work on this.

I‚Äôve been playing around with the recently upgraded @GitHub Actions and it was surprisingly easy to port some CircleCI jobs. Some intriguing features!

(The jobs are a little slower, but I suspect that‚Äôs largely due to the lack of dependency caching, and they‚Äôre working on that.)
As someone who likes both beer and kombucha, I thought I might like this. And I was right. Good stuff!

This is amazing: noparkinghere.com

/via @daveliepmann
Don‚Äôt tell my kid ‚Äî I‚Äôm selling our Mini. She is NOT happy. üòÖ

App idea: Reliable Regular Reminders. Pops up reminders reliably at the designated time ‚Äî daily, weekly, fortnightly, monthly, etc ‚Äî¬†and each ‚Äúinstance‚Äù of each reminder is supplanted by the following ‚Äúinstance‚Äù.

(Yeah, I‚Äôm really frustrated with the iOS Reminders app.)

Interesting idea came up in a recent chat with a colleague: that remote members of hybrid teams need on-site allies to speak up on their behalf, to make sure in-person meetings are recorded, or notes are shared; to address A/V issues; to invite them to ad-hoc meetings, etc.
First text message from the kid üòÇ
This is amazing ‚Äî the authors of the tool Kodiak documented the differences between it and 13 alternatives in an extremely clear table. I ‚ù§Ô∏èthis!
I stumbled downstairs this morning to find the kid (6) playing a math game on her device! üòÆü•≥
Idea: a feedback escrow service
@pyrmont cool! ping me if I can help with anything at all ‚Äî¬†I love nerding out on this stuff!

I ‚ù§Ô∏è git hooks, but I‚Äôm happier now that I‚Äôve converted my pre-commit hook to a pre-push hook. Turns out I like to commit often, even ‚Äî especially ‚Äî¬†when the work is still a mess ‚Äî¬†and clean it up before pushing. This new setup lets me stay in the flow!
@pyrmont fellow Clojurist here! I‚Äôm using it to build/maintain the tool that‚Äôs half of my docs-as-code software architecture diagramming framework: fundingcircle.github.io/fc4-frame...

US citizens/residents: if, like me, you‚Äôre giving Amazon more of your hard-earned money today or tomorrow during their contrived day of consumption, please join me in giving matching donations to RAICES or any org working to help immigrants and refugees at our southern border.
Yum
See You Yesterday is a wonderful film. Moving, fun, intriguing, and exciting. Highly recommended!

Just published my highlights from the wonderful Write the Docs Portland 2019 conference ‚Äî I‚Äôm super grateful that this conference exists and I was able to attend!

#writethedocs

Just gave a fun little talk at the #writethedocs PDX 2019 unconference: Storytelling with Git.

I‚Äôd love some suggestions of other events or contexts that might be a good place for this talk!

BTW #writethedocs PDX 2019 is fantastic!

Anyone know of a way to use @github‚Äôs ‚Äúteam discussions‚Äù feature to host fully public discussions in a public repo? So far my impression is it that it‚Äôs oriented around internal discussions within an org. I‚Äôd love to use @discourse but my project isn‚Äôt big enough üòû ‚Äî yet! üòÖ

üíø Young Enough by Charly Bliss üíø Morbid Stuff by PUP üíø Father of the Bride by Vampire Weekend üíø This Land by Gary Clark Jr. üíø There Will Be No Intermission by Amanda Palmer üíø Tides of a Teardrop by Mandolin Orange

Standardizing WASI: A system interface to run WebAssembly outside the web

I just got a replacement debit card from my bank; apparently they‚Äôre proactively upgrading everyone in my area to contactless cards for use with public transit. Cool, but in addition to the contactless feature and the chip, my new card also has old school raised numbers! üßêüòÇüò≠üòé

I‚Äôve been making software professionally for over 20 years, and I‚Äôm still baffled by how many of my peers dislike written communication.

We have dozens of information systems at our fingertips, but sure, let‚Äôs make decisions verbally and neglect to write down their rationales.

Whelp, my talk proposals to @WriteTheDocs Portland and OSCON have been rejected. üòû Won‚Äôt stop me from going back to Write the Docs though ‚Äî I was there last year for the first time and it was excellent. Tickets purchased! See you in May, Portland!

UK friends! I‚Äôll be speaking at the 7 March London Clojurians meetup at Funding Circle! My talk Growing a Clojure CLI Tool will be a case study in building and growing a usable CLI tool (one that runs tolerably on the JVM üòÖ). I hope to see you there!

I finished Kim Stanley Robinson‚Äôs new novel Red Moon last night. I thoroughly enjoyed it! As seems to be usual for his works, it‚Äôs a great mix of characters, ideas, and plot that combine into a compelling and thought-provoking experience. Similarly to his excellent New York 2140 it mana... blog.aviflax.com

I‚Äôve borrowed this Fiat 500E #bev for an extended test drive (fun!) and I think it might be shorter than my Mini Cooper (it‚Äôs certainly got much better visibility) so it seems I was able to park between two spaces!

I just finished the main story of Insomniac‚Äôs fantastic 2018 Spider-Man PS4 game and the scripted ending was gut-wrenching ‚Äî in a good way. This game felt like a lovingly crafted homage to the Spider-Man comics, and an earnest attempt to capture the magic of those comics. ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
SubEthaEdit is back! This takes me way back ‚Äî¬†I have the warm fuzzies for this app üòä. And now it‚Äôs FLOSS! Thank you @monkeydom!

New shell script to tell me when long-running processes are done ‚Äî tmwd, short for ‚Äútell me when done‚Äù

brew install terminal-notifier
echo "terminal-notifier -message 'Done"'!'"'" > ~/bin/tmwd
chmod +x ~/bin/tmwd

I use it like so:

run-tests; tmwd

üö®content warning: extremely geekyüö®

If I lived on a spaceship or space station that required one hour of maintenance every day to significantly reduce the risk of my premature death I would perform that maintenance every single day without fail.

So maybe I should take the same approach to maintaining my body.

I made a thing! The FC4 Framework is a methodology and a tool for authoring, publishing, and maintaining software architecture diagrams. It builds on the phenomenal work of Simon Brown.

Here‚Äôs its story: engineering.fundingcircle.com/blog/2018‚Ä¶

I really ‚ù§Ô∏è what @lynnetye is doing with @keyvaluesio. It‚Äôs super smart to connect potential employers and employees via (hopefully) shared values. Almost everything else flows from values; this makes way more sense than searching via other factors that are likely (weak) proxies!

I just noticed that Apple is renaming iBooks to just Books. I like it. I hope they‚Äôll drop the i prefix from all their products. Like Apple Watch and Apple TV, they‚Äôd have Apple Phone, Apple Pad, Apple Mac.

The Mac line would make sense:

Mac Mac Pro Mac Mini MacBook MacBook Pro
I love the smell of an impending merge disaster in the morning.

Whenever I have trouble with an Avro schema, a good way I‚Äôve found to debug it is by trying to generate ‚Äúrandom‚Äù example data using avro-tools.jar, like so:

java -jar avro-tools-1.8.2.jar random --schema-file TimeZone.avsc --count 1 -

But that didn‚Äôt take long, and I suspect it‚Äôs because it really does match the behavior on the X. It‚Äôs quite close. I suspect if/when I upgrade my X to iOS 12 they‚Äôll feel nearly identical.

@jl\_siewert interesting. Yes, but it does feel unified for someone using an iPad and an iPhone X, like me. I‚Äôd guess that all new iPhones going forward will use the new model. Possibly yet another case of Apple prioritizing ‚Äúthe future‚Äù over current user‚Äôs realities. Just curious: do you use an iPhone 8(s) or a prior model?

I just installed the iOS 12 beta on my iPad and I‚Äôm glad to see that it unifies the quick-switching interactions of the iPad and iPhone X (maybe all iPhones, I don‚Äôt know). Using both devices with their inconsistent interactions on iOS 11 was consistently annoying.

I‚Äôm also being reminded constantly that I still despise the usage of ‚Äúindividual contributor‚Äù to describe people who are not managers. The best work is usually done in collaboration with others!

#LeadDevNewYork
@matigo my pleasure!

@matigo this excellent post does a great job of explaining the main reasons that GraphQL is often a better choice than REST: www.braintreepayments.com/blog/grap...

I‚Äôd summarize it as: REST is an architectural style, which means there are many decisions to make and document when designing and implementing a RESTful API. Way too many. GraphQL, on the other hand, is a specification, akin to a protocol, wherein all the decisions have been made and documented already ‚Äî and they‚Äôre good decisions. While it‚Äôs certainly possible to design, implement, and operate an excellent RESTful API that‚Äôs secure, intuitive, well-documented, flexible, explorable, etc, it‚Äôs costly (in terms of time+effort and/or expertise) to do so. GraphQL democratizes excellent APIs by making all the desirable properties achievable quickly at low cost.
A feedback message I just sent to TD Bank on their apps blog.aviflax.com

@eli GraphQL is üíØ ‚Äî exactly what I have in mind to replace REST for most Web APIs. My personal (untested) hypothesis is that it can be used instead of REST in almost all cases. Maybe even your side project? Have you considered giving it a try?

@eli ah cool, yeah, that‚Äôs interesting. I guess when your product/service targets developers, a very specific approach is needed to market it. It might be broader though; maybe including education, training, and more actively conveying feedback between the customers and builders.

@eli that‚Äôs so cool! I‚Äôve lost interest as I‚Äôm kinda sick of REST, but I‚Äôd love to hear if you use it or not, or if it‚Äôs useful or not. Also you‚Äôre welcome to submit changes to it; I don‚Äôt think anyone is using it. How are you finding Clojure so far, BTW?

I‚Äôm grateful for the pioneering work of:

  • Ada Lovelace
  • Hedy Lamar
  • Jean Bartik
  • Grace Hopper
  • Fran Allen
  • Barbara Liskov
  • Jeannette Wing
  • Adele Goldberg
  • Susan Kare
  • Shafi Goldwasser

and the many more woman pioneers of computer science! I owe them my career and more.

Docker tip: if you specify --quiet or -q you can use the output of docker build as input to docker run:

ID=`docker build --quiet .` docker run -it --rm $ID

or:

docker run `docker build -q .`
